intro: Atalantia pseudoracemosa, commonly known as the false whitebark, is a species of flowering plant in the family Rutaceae. It is native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, where it typically grows in dry, rocky habitats. The plant is characterized by its compound leaves and small, fragrant flowers that bloom in spring. Its fruits are woody capsules that split open to release seeds. Atalantia pseudoracemosa is adapted to arid environments and plays a role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various insects and birds.
